title: The Space Museum
dialogue_disasters: Have any arms fallen into Xeron hands?
goofs: Ian says they are wearing 13th-century clothes, but the previous story was set in the 12th-century.
When they leave the TARDIS, their shadows are cast over the distant mountains.
It's unclear how the Doctor gets the Time Space Visualiser into the TARDIS.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine
continuity_notes.current_status: Has a 'lights' control on the console

continuity_notes.name: Moroks
continuity_notes.description: An alien race with a collapsed empire
continuity_notes.current_status: Maintaining a Space Museum on Xeros

continuity_notes.name: Daleks
continuity_notes.description: Infamous alien race known for invading Earth

continuity_notes.name: Time Space Visualiser
continuity_notes.description: A device found in the museum

technobabble: Time, like space, although a dimension of itself, also has dimensions of its own.
The Moroks are armed with 'ray guns'.
roots: The complexities of time-lines, as presented in The Twilight Zone
Renaissance subterfuge of chairs that trap sitting people

locations.name: Space Museum
locations.description: A museum on the planet Xeros, containing artifacts from the Morok Empire
locations.current_status: Active museum, site of conflict between Moroks and Xerons

locations.name: Xeros
locations.current_status: Three light years from the Morok planet, post-2493

future_history: Vicki mentions that scientists from Earth were working on the Time Space Visualiser when she left in 2493.
untold_adventures: The Doctor claims he was with James Watt when he discovered steam power.
qv: The Chase for more fun with cardigans
The Mind Robber, The Time Monster, The Creature from the Pit and The Horns of Nimon for more Minotaurs
additional_notes: William Hartnell has difficulty pronouncing 'fluorescent' when explaining the light source in the museum.
bottom_line: A silly 'fascists-and-rebels' runaround following a very weird first episode.
